unnormalised: So, about rental agreements in India… it's more than just a formality before you move into that awesome flat in Bandra, right? Think of it like your "janam patri" for your tenancy!
normalised: So, about rental agreements in India… it's more than just a formality before you move into that awesome flat in Bandra, right? Think of it like your "janam patri" for your tenancy!

unnormalised: Seriously though, a well-drafted rental agreement can save you a LOT of headaches down the line. Ever dealt with a landlord who suddenly “forgets” about that agreement to repaint before you moved in? Or disputes about security deposit refunds? Ugh!
normalised: Seriously though, a well-drafted rental agreement can save you a lot of headaches down the line. Ever dealt with a landlord who suddenly “forgets” about that agreement to repaint before you moved in? Or disputes about security deposit refunds? Ugh!

unnormalised: Make sure EVERYTHING is clearly specified. Rent amount, due date (e.g., 5th of every month), late payment penalties, maintenance charges (is Rajat responsible or the landlord?), and most importantly, the duration of the agreement. Typically 11 months to avoid registration hassles, right? But if you plan to stay longer, consider a registered lease agreement.
normalised: Make sure everything is clearly specified. Rent amount, due date (e.g., fifth of every month), late payment penalties, maintenance charges (is Rajat responsible or the landlord?), and most importantly, the duration of the agreement. Typically eleven months to avoid registration hassles, right? But if you plan to stay longer, consider a registered lease agreement.

unnormalised: And read the fine print! Who's responsible for what repairs? What are the termination clauses? Can Mrs. Sharma from the building committee object to your late-night parties (asking for a friend!)?
normalised: And read the fine print! Who's responsible for what repairs? What are the termination clauses? Can Mrs. Sharma from the building committee object to your late-night parties (asking for a friend!)?

unnormalised: I signed a pretty bad one back in 2018 (mistakes happen!) with clauses that basically favoured the landlord at every turn. Lesson learnt.
normalised: I signed a pretty bad one back in two thousand and eighteen (mistakes happen!) with clauses that basically favoured the landlord at every turn. Lesson learnt.

unnormalised: Also, remember to note the lock-in period! If you break the lease before, say, 6 months (starting 01/01/2024) – there can be financial implications. Get it all in writing!
normalised: Also, remember to note the lock-in period! If you break the lease before, say, six months (starting first january two thousand and twenty four) – there can be financial implications. Get it all in writing!

unnormalised: Finally, make sure both parties sign it in the presence of witnesses (and ideally, before 17:00 hrs on any given weekday – just kidding… mostly!). A digital agreement with Aadhar-based e-signatures is also perfectly valid these days, easier for verification purposes, and usually less Rs.500 than a physical registration.
normalised: Finally, make sure both parties sign it in the presence of witnesses (and ideally, before five PM on any given weekday – just kidding… mostly!). A digital agreement with Aadhar-based e-signatures is also perfectly valid these days, easier for verification purposes, and usually less rupee five hundred than a physical registration.
